name: aluminium sulfate production, powder | aluminium sulfate, powder | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/2258/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of aluminium sulfate. Aluminium sulfate (Al2(SO4)3) in its anhydrous forms a white powder, readily soluble in water. Aluminium sulfate is the second most important industrial compound of alumnium after aluminium oxide. Aluminium sulfate is mainly used for treating water and about one half of the total production goes into the paper industry. In Germany and most European countries, aluminium sulfate is produced primarily from aluminium hydroxide and sulfuric acid by the Giulini process. This dataset is based on information provided in a filled in questionnaire by one European company.;References:;Hischier R. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Packagings & Graphical Papers. ecoinvent-Report No. 11, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.;Helmboldt, O., Keith Hudson, L., Misra, C., Wefers, K., Heck, W., Stark, H., Danner, M. and Rösch, N. 2007. Aluminum Compounds, Inorganic. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry. 1–17.

The activity starts when the raw materials enter the process.

This activity ends with the production of aluminium sulfate. It includes the processing of the raw input materials, as well as the energy consumption for production. No emissions are included apart from water.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data from 1995, confirmed as still valid by the same company.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data used are from one single company in Europe. They are used as an average dataset for RER (Europe).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Data based on the information from one European producer. The inventory is based on a filled in questionnaire. The technology refers to the production of aluminium sulfate from aluminium hydroxide and sulfuric acid through the Giulini process.;Reference(s): ;Hischier R. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Packagings & Graphical Papers. ecoinvent-Report No. 11, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, 2007.;Helmboldt, O., Keith Hudson, L., Misra, C., Wefers, K., Heck, W., Stark, H., Danner, M. and Rösch, N. 2007. Aluminum Compounds, Inorganic. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry. 1–17.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data based on filled in form of one single company and expanded with standard approximations according to methodology of study.

exchanges.description:
Aluminium sulfate (Al2(SO4)3) in its anhydrous forms a white powder, readily soluble in water. Aluminium sulfate is the second most important industrial compound of alumnium after aluminium oxide. Aluminium sulfate is mainly used for treating water and about one half of the total production goes into the paper industry. 

References:

exchanges.description: Data in Habersatter 1998 - verified with producer

Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.
